trans-unit.source: Build a Service Using a Non-Relational Data Store | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Build a Service Using a Non-Relational Data Store | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use a non-relational data store such as MongoDB or Azure Table Storage with your .NET based mobile service
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use a non-relational data store such as MongoDB or Azure Table Storage with your .NET based mobile service

trans-unit.source: This topic shows you how to use a non-relational data store for your .NET backend mobile service.
trans-unit.target: This topic shows you how to use a non-relational data store for your .NET backend mobile service.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will modify the Mobile Services quickstart project to use MongoDB instead of the default Azure SQL Database data store.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will modify the Mobile Services quickstart project to use MongoDB instead of the default Azure SQL Database data store.

trans-unit.source: The tutorial requires completion of the [Get started with Mobile Services] or [Add Mobile Services to an existing app] tutorial.
trans-unit.target: The tutorial requires completion of the [Get started with Mobile Services] or [Add Mobile Services to an existing app] tutorial.

trans-unit.source: You will also need to add the MongoLab service to your subscription.
trans-unit.target: You will also need to add the MongoLab service to your subscription.

trans-unit.source: In the [Azure Management Portal], click New and click Marketplace.
trans-unit.target: In the [Azure Management Portal], click New and click Marketplace.

trans-unit.source: Click the MongoLab add-on, and complete the wizard to sign up for a MongoLab account.
trans-unit.target: Click the MongoLab add-on, and complete the wizard to sign up for a MongoLab account.

trans-unit.source: For more information about MongoLab, see the [MongoLab Add-on Page].
trans-unit.target: For more information about MongoLab, see the [MongoLab Add-on Page].

trans-unit.source: Once the account is set up, click Connection Info and copy the connection string.
trans-unit.target: Once the account is set up, click Connection Info and copy the connection string.

trans-unit.source: In your mobile service, click the Configure tab, scroll down to Connection strings and enter a new connection string with a Name of MongoConnectionString and a Value that is your MongoDB connection, then click Save.
trans-unit.target: In your mobile service, click the Configure tab, scroll down to Connection strings and enter a new connection string with a Name of MongoConnectionString and a Value that is your MongoDB connection, then click Save.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add the MongoDB connection string</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add the MongoDB connection string</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The storage account connection string is stored encrypted in app settings.
trans-unit.target: The storage account connection string is stored encrypted in app settings.

trans-unit.source: You can access this string in any table controller at runtime.
trans-unit.target: You can access this string in any table controller at runtime.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer in Visual Studio, open the Web.config file for the mobile service project and add the following new connection string:
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer in Visual Studio, open the Web.config file for the mobile service project and add the following new connection string:

trans-unit.source: Replace the placeholder with the MongoDB connection string.
trans-unit.target: Replace the placeholder with the MongoDB connection string.

trans-unit.source: The mobile service uses this connection string when it runs on your local computer, which lets you test the code before you publish it.
trans-unit.target: The mobile service uses this connection string when it runs on your local computer, which lets you test the code before you publish it.

trans-unit.source: When running in Azure, the mobile service instead uses the connection string value set in the portal and ignores the connection string in the project.
trans-unit.target: When running in Azure, the mobile service instead uses the connection string value set in the portal and ignores the connection string in the project.

trans-unit.source: Install the WindowsAzure.MobileServices.Backend.Mongo NuGet package.
trans-unit.target: Install the WindowsAzure.MobileServices.Backend.Mongo NuGet package.

trans-unit.source: Modify TodoItem to derive from DocumentData instead of EntityData.
trans-unit.target: Modify TodoItem to derive from DocumentData instead of EntityData.

trans-unit.source: In TodoItemController, replace the Initialize method with the following:
trans-unit.target: In TodoItemController, replace the Initialize method with the following:

trans-unit.source: In the code for the Initialize method above, replace with the name you chose when you provisioned the MongoLab add-on.
trans-unit.target: In the code for the Initialize method above, replace with the name you chose when you provisioned the MongoLab add-on.

trans-unit.source: You are now ready to test the app.
trans-unit.target: You are now ready to test the app.

trans-unit.source: (Optional) Republish your mobile service .NET backend project.
trans-unit.target: (Optional) Republish your mobile service .NET backend project.

trans-unit.source: You can also test your mobile service locally before you publish the .NET backend project to Azure.
trans-unit.target: You can also test your mobile service locally before you publish the .NET backend project to Azure.

trans-unit.source: Whether you test locally or in Azure, the mobile service will be using your MongoDB for storage.
trans-unit.target: Whether you test locally or in Azure, the mobile service will be using your MongoDB for storage.

trans-unit.source: Using either the Try it now button on the start page as before or using a client app connected to your Mobile App, query items in the database.
trans-unit.target: Using either the Try it now button on the start page as before or using a client app connected to your Mobile App, query items in the database.

trans-unit.source: Note that you will not see any items which were previously stored in the SQL database from the quickstart tutorial.
trans-unit.target: Note that you will not see any items which were previously stored in the SQL database from the quickstart tutorial.

trans-unit.source: When you use the Try it now button to launch the Help API pages, remember to supply your application key as the password (with a blank username).
trans-unit.target: When you use the Try it now button to launch the Help API pages, remember to supply your application key as the password (with a blank username).

trans-unit.source: Create a new item.
trans-unit.target: Create a new item.

trans-unit.source: The app and mobile service should behave as before, except now your data is being stored in your non-relational store instead of in the SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: The app and mobile service should behave as before, except now your data is being stored in your non-relational store instead of in the SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: Now that you have seen how easy it is to use Table storage with .NET backend, consider exploring some other backend storage options:
trans-unit.target: Now that you have seen how easy it is to use Table storage with .NET backend, consider exploring some other backend storage options:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Build a .NET backend Mobile Service that uses Table storage instead of a SQL Database</linkText><title></title></br>Like the tutorial you just completed, this topic shows you how to use a non-relational data store for your mobile service. In this tutorial, you will modify the Mobile Services quickstart project to use Azure Storage instead of a SQL Database as the data store.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Build a .NET backend Mobile Service that uses Table storage instead of a SQL Database</linkText><title></title></br>Like the tutorial you just completed, this topic shows you how to use a non-relational data store for your mobile service. In this tutorial, you will modify the Mobile Services quickstart project to use Azure Storage instead of a SQL Database as the data store.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Connect to an on-premises SQL Server using Hybrid Connections</linkText><title></title></br>Hybrid Connections lets your mobile service securely connect to your on-premises assets. In this way, you can make your on-premises data accessible to your mobile clients by using Azure. Supported assets include any resource that runs on a static TCP port, including Microsoft SQL Server, MySQL, HTTP Web APIs, and most custom web services.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Connect to an on-premises SQL Server using Hybrid Connections</linkText><title></title></br>Hybrid Connections lets your mobile service securely connect to your on-premises assets. In this way, you can make your on-premises data accessible to your mobile clients by using Azure. Supported assets include any resource that runs on a static TCP port, including Microsoft SQL Server, MySQL, HTTP Web APIs, and most custom web services.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Upload images to Azure Storage using Mobile Services</linkText><title></title></br>Shows you how to extend the TodoList sample project to let you upload images from your app to Azure Blob storage.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Upload images to Azure Storage using Mobile Services</linkText><title></title></br>Shows you how to extend the TodoList sample project to let you upload images from your app to Azure Blob storage.
